--- Philip Tucker <ptucker@...> wrote:

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green
> <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > As well as additive mutations, crossover also
> results in structure
> > being copied throughout a population and quite
> possibly faster than
> > deletion mutations can remove them. Also the
> speciation in standard
> 
> I don't see how crossover can contribute to bloat,
> though.  A child
> is, structurally, a clone of the dominant parent
> (i.e., the parent
> with highest fitness).  Crossover only occurs in the
> weights of
> connections shared by both parents.
> 
> That's the way we implemented it in ANJI, anyway. 
> Have others done
> differently, where the child contains a union of
> parent genes?

I think in Ken's original, unmatched genes from either
parent are taken into the child, but a separate case
is made where the range of genes in one parent extends
beyond the range in the other (e.g. where an
innovation number > than the max innovation in the
other), and I think those are taken only from the
dominant parent.

In my case I currently take all unmatched genes.  This
is partly because I wasn't sure I liked Ken's reasons
for his scheme, partly because my innovation numbers
are more complex, and partly just because I didn't get
around to trying anything else yet.

I have tried to get my head around how crossover
influences bloat and I find it resists easy analysis.

Clearly without crossover, the equilibrium situation
is where:

insertion_prob = deletion_prob * num_genes

(e.g. assuming that deletion is a separate chance for
each gene, the most ration scheme to my mind).

But crossover changes that, by forming unions of pairs
of individuals.  I'm wondering whether, vis-a-vis my
"assymetric parentage" discussion in the other thread,
a 50% chance of keeping an unmatched gene is the
correct approach...

Ian
